remarks: GENERAL COMMENT. General rewriting of a SATB model in a Missa a vocibus paribus TTTB (meaning S of model is most of the time transposed 8- in Mass).
La voix de ténor primus cite intégralement le bassus du modèle
Deux brèves de silence interpolées m.16 et 17 à la voix de tenor primus
The Canon at Unisson 4 breves is made possible by the interpolation of 2 pauses (mes. 16-17 and 33-34)
Several repetitions of Sogetto, one first note added (4th below)
This ID is only the basis of a very free Fg, developed on 'Vidi speciosam sicut columbam'.
The ID has been reproduced with regular entries, which probably explains the slight changes in the melodic lines.
"flexed entries": motif à S et B commence par une semi-brève, à Q et T par une minime
Légères modifications dans le Kyrie: m.5 T, m.6 T2, m.8 T2/C, fin de T2.
Le motif à S peut être considéré comme "sogetto", et le motif à C comme son "counter sogetto": rapport d'intervalles caractéristique (3)/5/8/5
Les valeurs rythmiques du "sogetto" et "counter sogetto" ont été modifiées, mais on retrouve les intervalles caractéristiques  du "contrapuntal duo": (1)/5/8/5
m.14, B participe à la "fuga" mais les valeurs rythmiques sont changées: seule voix à citer exactement le "sogetto" du modèle
"Quotation monnayage" du sogetto de la chanson (valeurs rythmiques modifiées), traité en "fuga".
"Flexed entries": valeur rythmique de la première note
"Quotation monnayage" du counter sogetto de la chanson, traité en fugue.

The fuga is based on an ID I have already asserted in another comment. It is hard to find any other structural element in this fuga, as it is quite free. The first kyrie is based on only one element, leading to the CAD.

A very free fuga based on an idea asserted in another comment. I have indicated a CAD that is not really a CAD, as to compare with the mass. This whole song, anyway, counts a lot of cadential clausules for very few CAD actually audible, due to a lot of dovetails and a 'restless' behaviour. The CAD I selected is inverted, I cannot indicate it... As the soggetto of 'Vidi speciosam' is used again on 'Cuius inastimabilis', I have selected the latter, though I do not describe it. (after reflection, I find the actual CAD on bar 28, it could be the model of the CAD in the mass. I will indicate it in another comment)

There are two ways to interpret this relationship. The first one is to consider that Sohier has amplified the first Fg in order to make his first Kyrie. The second one is to consider he has seen 'Vidi speciosam' and 'cuius inaestimabilis' as one and the same Fg, broken by another soggetto ('de super rivos aquarum') that he has decided to omit in his missa.

The position of the clausules (tenorizans, cantizans and bassus) is the same, and the two other voices behave with a delay that is quite comparable, which makes me think Sohier could have reproduced this CAD to finish his first Kyrie. I would not take any bet on this assertion, the model is not clearly structured - at least is very complex in its structure -, so it would not surprise me from Sohier to pick materials here and there in order to build his missa like a LEGO game...

In the second duo, the first entry has been anticipated, so that the counterpoint is the one of an ID, even though the time interval of entries is not 'regular'. The Primis Tenor enters in imitation, turning the ID into a Fg.
The 'change of voice role prevents me from asserting a quotation with monnayage, even though the time intervals and the notes are the same.
A fuga based on an ID.
A big fuga, quite free, starting on an ID, broken by several secundary soggetti.

This assertion is interesting on the point point of view of form. If we take into account that Sohier started his Christe on the material of 'Quae est ista quae proces sit', the second part of the model, we can assume that the first Kyrie quotes the whole first part of the song. 'Vidi speciosam' and 'cuius inaestimabilis' are built on the same soggetto, which start on a fifth can be considered to be found back in the cadential 'et lilia con valium'. Between these three sentences, several soggetti  have been omited by Sohier: 'ascendentem...', 'de super rivos', 'et sicut dies', circumdabant'. I assert a New combination, for I assume Sohier has taken three sentences and made them into one. We could also think, taking the omission into consideration, that the sentences of the model are just one big fuga, broken by some new soggetti, and that this fuga has been transformed with amplification and change of voice role.
A fuga that is quite free. I cannot find any 'bigger' structural element.

Once again, quite a free Fg. I really cannot describe it in another way, and it looks like it will be the same for all the material of this model.

The last soggetto of the model, leading do the final CAD. It starts with an ID, which is quite 'flexed', but I am so happy to find something else than a fuga... As the first voice of the second duo starts before the second voice of the first duo, the time intervals and intervals of entries will correspond to this order: TenorII, Superius, Bassus, Contra.

I want to consider the CAD as a quotation with monnayage, for the clausule of bassus is lead by an entry of the fuga with similar melody in the model and the mass. It is very fragile. For the whole Kyrie, Sohier does not find strong structural elements in the model, for this model is written quite freely. Only the soggetti are taken and turned into new fugas, this is why I indicated 'change of voice role' for every element I have studied.
The first voice of the second duo comes before the second voice of the first duo. The intervals are indicated after the order of apparition of the voices.
If we consider that the 5th entry starts at the beginning of the 9th bar, the time interval becomes S3/5/3/5/2.

The counter-soggetto is used to make a figuralism on 'descendit de'. It is anticipated at the bassus on 'Qui proper nos". As this diatonic descent is also the end of soggetto, it can be considered as anticipated by the soggetto ('Qui propter nos homines, et proper nostram').

The end of the soggetto (the diatonic descent) is used as a counter-soggetto of its own, becoming independent on 'circumdabant'. This fact is important for Sohier will use this characteristic to produce a figuralism. I consider that the third entry, on the contra, starts one M later, for it is the only one that is 'flexed'.

remarks: I am not certain about the amplification. The figuralism emphasizes the fact that the counter-soggetto comes from the end of the soggetto, so that we really hear it as an amplification of the soggetto...

It is truncated for the fuga becomes a NIM, so that the soggetto is only used twice in the mass. It is amplified for the little CAD becomes overlapping CAD, based on a NIM.

remarks: Such an important reduction/truncation that it could be considered an omision... if the text was not 'et invisibilium'. This section of the mass goes unnoticed in regard to 'visibilium ominum' that is built on the 'main theme' of the model. Sohier uses a quasi-omision to make a figuralism.
I deem the HR on 'Iesum Christum' important enough to be noticed as New Material.
The first entries are melodically reduced. The opening 5th/4th jump is replaced by a fall of 4th/5th that directly leads to the original third note of the soggetto.

A soggetto that we find back several pagesbefore. It is reused on 'et resurexit'. It is probably far-fetched, but we can consider that Sohier makes a figuralism by 'resuscitating' an old soggetto...

A soggetto that we find back several pages before. It is reused on 'et resurexit'. It is probably far-fetched, but we can consider that Sohier makes a figuralism by 'resuscitating' an old soggetto... I assess a reduction, for I do not know what else I could assess...
It looks like Sohier has reduced a former soggetto to turn it into a new soggetto, and built a fuga from it.
Apparently a New Material, I cannot find where it could come from...

Amplification de la petite fugue de la chanson: dans la messe, les trois voix supérieures sont impliquées, on a au total 8 entrées du motifs étalées sur 15 mesures. A partir de m.42, le superius reprend seul le motif à trois reprises, en guise de clausule.

It's quite the same thing, we can note just few omissions and ornementations. The reduction concerns bars 21-22 of the model: there are merged in one measure in the mass (cf. bar 20).
Chant melody ornamented with passing notes (crotchet A, G)
Last note of chant segment embellished with a cantizans cadential figure
The first two entrances are strict, as usual; the third is freely diminished in rhythm and lacks its final note (or one could say the final melodic interval is flexed from a 2nd, A-G to a 3rd, A-F)

The altus and bassus make use of two repeated motives: (1) a rising "cumulative fourth" consisting of a rising second + rising third in minims, and (2) a stepwise falling fourth in dotted minim & crotchets. In one place in the altus the two motives are spliced together to form a countermelody beneath the first note of the soggetto; otherwise they occur separately. The motives don't line up with the subject consistently, so they don't form NIms. Could be considered "contrapunto fugato"?

remarks: The last entry of this fuga is shorter in the mass (M6) than in the model (M7)

The superius and tenor are in strict fuga at the lower fifth, as usual in this piece. The altus also follows the bassus in strict fuga at the lower fourth, but only the first two notes of the soggetto are the same between the superius/tenor and bassus/altus pairs. Possible hypothesis: having established the superius/tenor framework, Mouton attempted to elaborate it into a full four-voice stacked canon, but was forced to alter the third and fourth entrances because of contrapuntal difficulties?

Superius/tenor in strict fuga at the lower fifth as usual. Third entrance in the altus truncated after its fourth note, after which it continues in free counterpoint. Fourth entrance dubious, if it is considered an imitative entrance at all: it comprises only the first two notes, with the interval between them flexed from a 2nd to a 3rd.

The chant melody has a built-in repetition at this point, and Mouton sets both repetitions identically, meaning that the complete four-voice complex formed by superius/tenor fuga + free altus and bassus is immediately repeated, without any change or exchange of voices,

remarks: This long soggetto in the mass may be a reminiscence of a counter soggetto, at the very beginning

The third entrance (altus) is flexed between its first and second notes, so that Eb-Eb replaces D-Eb. This could be considered an entrance at the second above the tenor (changing the intervals to 5-2+4+5-) but it seems better to judge from the remainder of the subject, excluding the "flexed" first note. The final two entrances in superius and tenor are freely augmented (but strict in respect to each other, except for the lengths of the first two notes).

Comme nous l'avons dit dans l'observation précédente, le duo SA de la chanson m.50-53 est repris trois fois dans la messe, à partir de m.94. Les deuxième et troisième fois, ce duo est accompagné par le nouveau "contresujet" sélectionné, la première fois en duo, BT2, la deuxième fois à T seul.
Ce new countersubject remplace la voix de T2 à la première exposition du duo m.94, qui elle reprend exactement la chanson.

There is an entry (Tenor, bars 10-12) that I did not include in the EMA citation, because its head is different from the soggetto of the fuga, but the conclusion (which overlaps with the first entry of the fuga) is the same.

remarks:
The initial note in the bassus in the mass has been transposed up an octave, altering the melodic interval from the expected 4+ to 5-. This alteration moves the bassus into a more "comfortable" range than it would have been had it strictly adhered to the global transposition of 5-.
Additionally, the final two notes of the superius line in the model were condensed in the mass from two minims to two semiminims.
Because the length of the quoted material in the superius and tenor parts matches, as does the length of the material quoted in the contratenor and bassus parts, this could alternatively be understood as Marle quoting two simultaneous contrapuntal duos, an assertion that would not be made about the material in the model without seeing it through the lens of Marle's quotation. (Since the form does not allow me to select multiple contrapuntal duos, these will be cited separately)
Can only be understood as a CD in light of Marle's borrowing.
Can only be understood as a CD in light of Marle's borrowing.
Can only be understood as a CD in light of Marle's borrowing.
Can only be understood as a CD in light of Marle's borrowing.
Inverted, evaded. Superius, tenor, and bassus all dovetail by articulating the next line of text at the point where the cadence is expected to end.
The bassus retains the melodic motion presented in the earlier quotation of this passage (5-). This quotation is a transposition of the earlier quotation of the same passage (4-).
Can only be understood as a CD in light of Marle's borrowing.

remarks:
Cadence m.43-44
Écriture en contrepoint libre, syllabique, proche de l'homorythmie.

Le matériau polyphonique du modèle est cité aux cinq voix, avec quelques modifications rythmiques.
cadence m.51

Cadence m.35-36
Les entrées de Q et B ne font pas partie de la fuga car les intervalles mélodiques sont différents ; cependant, leur structure rythmique et la disposition des entrées incite à les entendre comme participant au mouvement fugué.
Citation aux 5 voix du matériau polyphonique de la chanson. Quelques légères modifications rythmiques à l’intérieur des voix, liées au placement du texte.
Two added entries, turning the ID into a fuga.
Even though the contra comes a bit early, I count it as periodic entries.

remarks:
On peut considérer: 
- la voix de S comme sogetto
- les voix de A et T comme contrapuntal duo (mouvement continu en notes noires)
- les voix de Q et B comme deuxième contrapuntal duo (interval patterns: chain 85)

Transformation truncated: concerne le sogetto à S, qui dans la messe s'arrête sur le la avec le motif d'imitation (see assertion) et ne fait pas entendre la fin du motif de la chanson, ré-ré-sib (m.30-31).
La fuga sur le motif rythmique peut être considéré comme un new material car il n'est pas issu de la chanson.Ce new material sert de jonction entre les deux citations polyphoniques "elle leur dit" et "de ce corps mien", et se dissout dans cette seconde citation.
La relationship omission semble pertinente car le compositeur évacue clairement le passage "par deloyauté" pour le remplacer par la fuga.
The soggetto has been flexed in the tenor entry by shortening of duration of the second note, forcing the bassus to come in one minim before its expected entry in order to maintain the module.
It can also be an Imitative duos A>S, B>T

First entrie of the Fuga (missing the head motif)

It can also be a Non-Imitative Duos
S>T S2 @8-
        S8
A>B S2 @8-
Omission of the ConterSubject if we take it as the base of the Relationship

remarks: Le Nim de la chanson (deux couples) est présenté une troisième fois dans la messe  : sujet au tenor (troisième entrée de la fugue), contre-sujet tronqué au bassus.
Du Nim de la chanson, Lassus conserve uniquement l'imitation du contre-sujet. Ce motif peut être perçu comme le nouveau sogetto dans la messe.
Le contresujet de la chanson est traité en PEn dans le credo.
Motif mélodique de la chanson de Lupi traité en fugue dans le credo.
Contrapuntal duo SA + B
Contrapuntal duo SA + Q

Quotation monnayage: valeurs rythmiques légèrement modifiées.
Trans mech: la voix de Q dans la chanson est chanté au B dans la messe
Flexed entries: valeur rythmique de la première note inégale entre les différentes entrées
L'homorythmie concerne aussi la voix de B mais son motif n'est pas réutilisé dans le credo.
Dans la chanson, le motif et son renversement sont entendus simultanément, en homorythmie ; dans la messe, ils sont décalés, car traités en fugue, et transposés.
The soggetti of the first duo contain an anticipation of the counter subject. Added voices at Quintus and Tenor II.
Added voices at Contra, Sup, and TI.

remarks: The alternance of 2 and 6 minimes gives kind of a periodicity to the Fuga.
A 'funny' time interval behaviour, with voices getting further one to the other: M2/3/4/5 twice.
La voix de T sert de soutien harmonique au premier duo (do sib fa), la voix de B au second duo (mib sib fa)
La voix de Q sert de soutien harmonique au premier duo (do sib fa), la voix de B au second duo (mib sib fa)
Le bicinium est accompagné par la voix de B
Le bicinium est accompagné par la voix de Q
Le bicinium de la chanson (SA m.50-53) est tronqué dans la messe, et amplifié rythmiquement à partir de la moitié. La voix de Q dans la chanson est passée au B dans la messe.

Transformation embellished: la voix de T est issue de la voix de Q dans la chanson mais est très ornée dans la messe.
Transformation amplified: le milieu de la citation (do-sib au S, chanson m.50) est divisée par deux rythmiquement, à toutes les voix.
